title: Reverse a Linked List
prompt:
Given the head of a singly linked list, return the head of the list after reversing it.

Linked list node shape:
- value (or val): the node's value
- next: reference to the next node (or null)

Edge cases:
- If head is null, return null.
- If the list has one node, return the same node.
constraintQuestions: Is this a singly linked list? (Yes.)
What should we return for null input? (null.)
Can we reverse in-place (mutating next pointers)? (Yes.)
Do we need an iterative solution without knowing the length? (Yes.)
Should we aim for O(n) time and O(1) extra space? (Yes.)

walkthrough.title: Iterative pattern (we only get the head)
walkthrough.body:
We don't know the list length, so we traverse node-by-node.
Use a while loop that repeatedly operates on the current node, then moves forward:
current = current.next
The key is updating pointers without losing the rest of the list.

walkthrough.title: Pointer reversal technique (prev / current / next)
walkthrough.body:
Maintain:
- prev: head of the reversed portion (starts null)
- current: node we're processing (starts head)
- next: temporary saved reference to current.next
Steps:
1) next = current.next
2) current.next = prev
3) prev = current
4) current = next
When current becomes null, prev is the new head.
Time: O(n)
Space: O(1)
